title: Some N.J. Nursing Homes Will Resume Visitations
text:
Those requirements include no active cases for 14 days and sufficient staff and personal protective equipment.

The counties where long-term-care facilities are now eligible for indoor visits are Hunterdon, Mercer, Somerset, Burlington, Camden, Gloucester and Salem, said Ms. Persichilli.

"This is good news. We are seeing outbreaks in our long-term-care facilities decrease," Ms. Persichilli said.

Vaccinations are also continuing at long-term-care facilities across the state, Ms. Persichilli said.

So far, the federal effort to administer inoculations at nursing homes led by CVS Health Corp. and Walgreens Boots Alliance Inc. has resulted in more than 230,000 long-term-care residents and staff in New Jersey getting vaccinated, she said.

Overall, the state has administered 1.76 million doses of the Covid-19 vaccine.

New Jersey's seven-day average of Covid-19 cases was 2,934 on Tuesday, one of the lowest figures since mid-November. There were 2,070 people hospitalized on Tuesday with Covid-19 or probable cases, the lowest level since mid-November.

Gov. Phil Murphy, a Democrat, said Wednesday that the falling infection rates mean restaurants would be permitted to raise their indoor dining capacity to 50% "sooner rather than later."

The new variants of Covid-19, however, could complicate the easing of additional restrictions, depending on the infection rates, he added.

In New York, the daily positivity rate for Covid-19 tests on Tuesday fell to 2.85%, the lowest level since November 21. There were also 5,876 people hospitalized with Covid-19 in the state on Tuesday.

"New Yorkers have shown courage and fortitude in the face of this unprecedented pandemic, and it's thanks to them that we're seeing a decline in hospitalizations and in the Covid positivity rate," said New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo, a Democrat.
